p: We were able to demonstrate in our analysis that institutional trust was a protective factor. This is in line with previous studies indicating that people with higher institutional trust are more likely to follow the advice and guidelines given by the health authorities [ 16, 17]. In our analysis, COVID-19 mortality figures have progressed differently in low-trust countries and high-trust countries. Remarkably, some low-trust countries such as Italy, Spain, and France were not only late in placing restrictions but had to place harder measures later, such as curfews, because people were simply not following the recommendations not to socialize with each other. Despite hard measures, these countries have also had to sanction disobedient citizens. For example, the Ministry of Interior in Italy reported intensive controls, and over 100,000 people were caught by the police for breaking the curfew [ 32].
